ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about vector calculus, double and triple integrals, line integrals, surface integrals, and many other topics in multivariable calculus.
I had my first exposure to multivariable calculus.
I audit this course to prepare for my CS mater. This course is very helpful.
If this was the first time I was seeing this content, I would feel that Beth did a good job teaching and conveying difficult topics

It's an introduction to multivariable calculus. I learned some vector calculus, partial derivatives, double & triple integrals, etc. There are also some applications mentioned and I was able to make some connections between the math in this course and PHYS 181.
I gained a very solid understanding to multivariate calculus and its applications to other fields.
Multivariable calculus with an application to physics problems.

I learned all the basics of Calc III. More importantly, I learned how to use the resources in the class such as the tutoring that helped me tremendously. I also learned that office hours can go a long way in helping one grasp lessons.
I learned about multivariable calculus and how they relate to certain concepts in other fields of science.
Learned calculus concepts as they apply to both 3-space and 2-space. Line integrals, surface integrals, double and triple integrals, partial integration, partial derivatives,.
I learned a lot about multiple variable calculus and some of its engineering applications.
I learned a lot of multivariable calculus like double integrals, triple integrals, partial differentiation, Green's Theorem, Gauss' Theorem, Stokes' Theorem, and vector calculus.
a lot very good
How to work hard and think critically
knowledge of calculus of multiple variable; applications in physics, math, and general sciences.
Vectors, dot and cross products, double and triple integrals, line and surface integrals, cylindrical and spherical coordinates, applications of said concepts
Calc 3 math, including vectors, 3-space, quadric surfaces, and various theorems.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The live Q&A sections--particularly the practice problems, were essential for me to understand the course material.

Strengths: The course is very well organized to facilitate student learning and the professor is always in constant communication with students about what can be expected to happen in class, on the exam, etc. It is very easy for a student to find help when needed through the plethora of resources available (optional class sessions, very frequent office hours and drop-in help sessions, lecture notes, pset solutions). The professor also makes an effort to get to know her students, and she is also a great teacher, explaining things very clearly and telling us what tips may be helpful when doing a particular type of math problem. She is very approachable and I've had many positive interactions with her.
Weaknesses: None that come to mind.

Cant think of weaknesses; Professor Bennett did everything she could to supplement learning during COVID. When I didnt do well on the second midterm, she reached out to me and helped me find resources to improve my learning experiences.

I personally found myself having difficulty comprehending many of the concepts and applications taught in the course, but I think that of the options available for multivariable calculus, it's probably the strongest. Our professor was quite good; she worked actively to facilitate a sense of community among students despite our virtual semester, and she was proactive and timely with updates, information, and clarification. An interesting course made better by a very competent, education-focused, and caring professor. My one criticism is that I think it would have been helpful to work more with applications-based problems prior to the tests, and to spend less time on other, more rote-learning focused problems.
Sometimes the pre-recorded lectures were monotonous, but overall it was good

Professor Bennett is a great teacher. She listens to feedback. She made some helpful changes (like adding extra office hours) after we submitted mid-term feedback. The course is also organized and she provides great lecture notes.

A strength of the course was the format of the course. It was nice to watch the prerecorded lectures and then have an opportunity to ask questions about the lectures and get more practice during the optional biweekly office hours. A weakness fo the course was the length of the lectures. The lectures were very long and difficult to get through.
Professor Bennett was a very engaging lecturer! The recordings were fun to watch :). The only thing I would ask for is an in-person element, but that's definitely difficult now.
Strengths: Professor Bennett is incredible and makes complex material easy to understand. The recorded lectures allowed us to go at our own pace to make sure we understand the material.
Very organized course, concepts flowed and progression made sense in terms of content.
Strengths: Dr. Bennett's amazing teaching, communication, and organization
I think that the lack of virtual class was a weakness due to lack of structure. However, other than that the course is great and allows students to truly learn due to well recorded lectures.
This course was very well organized and the content, while conceptually high-level, was broken up into manageable parts.
I really appreciated the multiple office hours and peer tutor hours that were available for help. The recorded lectures were really long to do in one sitting but the concepts were explained clearly.
I really enjoyed the recorded lectures. Being able to pause and rewatch sections that I didn't initially grasp was extremely helpful. The lecture notes and practice exams were also super useful.
Very good feedback on homework and clear expectations. Extremely well-organized!
Very well structured course with a great professor!

The strengths of this class are clear explanations, very helpful lectures, plenty of guided examples, numerous office hours and drop-in help sessions, and resources like practice exams, lecture notes, and pset solutions. A weakness of this course is that the feedback and grading on the psets can be unclear as to how many points were taken off for a mistake and what the mistake was especially when the feedback was to look at the solutions and the solutions only had the answer with no math done.

I wish that the class didn't use as much jargon and that the tests were more similar to pset problems. I never figured out the key to taking the tests, and since it was online, it was really hard to learn with the recorded lectures.
so hard but so good.
Excellent course, I cannot think of any improvements

Strengths: the lectures were marvelously clear; I have never seen math explained so clearly and so effortlessly. Professor Bennett also took the time to meet her students and get to know them, despite the fact that we were all taking the course through a series of recorded lectures. Help was readily available for those who needed it, through TA office hours, QA sessions, and peer tutor help sessions.

Weaknesses: very few. I could not think of a better class to take if you are interested in mathematics or the sciences. Exams were tough, and the curve was not as generous ( I think partially because so many people had already seen the material in High School or other courses). However, the grading was straightforward and even someone like myself, who had never seen the material before, could succeed in the class.
The lecture videos provided example problems that assisted in understanding the material, and the problem sets correlated well with the exams.
There are many opportunities to learn the material, including the lectures, scheduled live zoom sessions, office hours, and in the extra  help sessions for students falling behind.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The in-class practice problems that replaced lecture time (since lectures were prerecorded). Also having prerecorded lecture provided a lot of flexibility.
Having a peer tutor to meet with once a week for small group tutoring was extremely helpful

The plethora of office hours availability and the option of attending the optional class sessions were great because they allowed a student with any sort question about a concept they are confused about to easily have their question answered.

I think its hard for students to keep up with the lectures when they dont have a set time to watch them, since they were all prerecorded (this is more of a problem on their behalf instead of the courses). I liked all the resources that were available for students though.

It was helpful to have recorded lectures and many office hours, but it did feel like I was expending far more time on this course than my other courses. Otherwise, the social and academic measures taken to make this a course adapted to the pandemic were well thought-out and succeeded in making this a generally good learning experience.
I think that I would appreciate some more engaging activities, but they were offered, I just was not incentivized to attend
I liked working through the recorded lectures on my own and then attending the virtual summary & practice meeting. However, I thought the meetings went too long sometimes.
The flexibility provided by the recorded lectures was very helpful!
I enjoyed have asynchronous prerecorded lectures, as it allowed me to absorb the material better and learn on my own time.
I think that the recorded lectures was awesome since they helped so much, but I would of preferred them being a pre-lecture and held a live virtual class.

I didn't attend many of the optional class time discussion sections. I struggled to watch some of the lectures ahead of time, so I didn't find them to be super useful. The practice problems from these recaps, however, were a useful study tool and the many drop in sessions helped me fill in most of the gaps in my understanding.
The numerous drop-in help sessions and office hours as well as the recap session after every recorded lecture really helped.
I think class should have been conducted synchronously to encourage engagement and allowing students to ask questions as they learned.
good teaching. Just pure good teachings.
100% succeeded

I could not think of a better example for how a class should be run during a pandemic year than this class. The material was taught so clearly and effectively in the lectures, and there were so many opportunities to meet with the staff of the course for help. Exams were open book, so no one could gain an advantage over using their notes etc. The class exams were proctored (to make sure no one used the internet) in small groups, and each exam included an honor pledge.

Despite the virtual learning, there were opportunities to interact with other students, as well as with Professor Bennett, in the live zoom classes, as well as in the various types of meetings Professor Bennett came up with. These implementations made the course more engaging than the rest of my courses.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If required for your major, yes.
Yes. It does ramp up at the end, but the content was well organized, and the professor is very helpful.
Yes, I would highly recommend this course! Professor Bennett is an amazing teacher and she always gives off positive vibes.
Its not easy. I dont think people would take it for fun (probably only for major requirements).

Yes, if you plan to pursue a career or work in a field where you would like to have practical (engineering) experience with the application of concepts from calculus. If you are taking this from personal interest or for a different goal (such as preparing for higher-level economics), it might be worth considering other maths courses more geared to your specific interest area.
I would, especially over math 120. I felt that it was a more fair representation of the content and that the professor's goal it to actually learn and absorb the content

Yes, I'd recommend this course. Prof Bennett is great. The course is geared towards future engineers (you don't write proofs) but you could definitely take this course even if you're not studying engineering.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It was very well organized and was a good progression from Math 115.
yes definitely take this over math 120 beth is the best
Yes! This is a perfect introduction to multivariable calculus in a stress-free environment.

YES. This course is magnitudes better than MATH120 and is objectively a good course. I actually enjoyed lectures quite a bit, because Prof Bennett focused to teaching us the relevant applications of the material and how we can solve various problems.
Yes, it was a nice introduction and review of multivariable calculus.
Yes, particularly if you do not like proofs but still want to learn how to apply calculus concepts in other areas!

Definitely, Dr.Bennett's classes should be something every STEM student experiences. In addition, Dr. Bennett is so supportive and genuinely strives to make her class a great learning experience for all.
Yes! Multivariable is a prerequisite for many majors and this course fulfills the same role as MATH 120, but is (in my opinion) organized better and taught more effectively.
Yes, this course was well organized and Professor Bennett is great! Even though I took calc 2 years ago in junior year of high school, the course was definitely managable.
Yes
If you're interested in engineering and math, I'd definitely recommend this class. I can't speak for any other instructors, but Dr. Bennett was terrific.
Yes! I shopped this class and traditional MATH 120 and found this class to be more engaging for me personally and a more manageable workload.
Yes, Prof. Bennett is a great and her lecture + lecture notes are very well organized

I would definitely recommend this course to other students because I found it to be designed to help student learning a lot. The math was more practical instead of theoretical (like proofs and deriving formulas) which I enjoyed. Professor Bennett also really teaches and explains the topics well so it's very easy and simple to understand.
nope. but I had to take it, so i'm sure others will continue to take it too.

Most people who take this class need it for their major, but definitely try to take it with Prof. Bennett if possible! The course is very well-organized and does not feel too fast-paced. The tests were sometimes difficult but always fair. I feel like I actually was able to absorb all of the material with the weekly PSETs and non-cumulative exams.
Yea good teacher and good lessons
Yes!

Yes. Yes. Yes. I have never seen math explained so clearly and so effortlessly. Professor Bennett also took the time to meet her students and get to know them, despite the fact that we were all taking the course through a series of recorded lectures. Help was readily available for those who needed it, through TA office hours, QA sessions, and peer tutor help sessions.

I could not think of a better example for how a class should be run during a pandemic year than this class. The material was taught so clearly and effectively in the lectures, and there were so many opportunities to meet with the staff of the course for help. Exams were open book, so no one could gain an advantage over using their notes etc. The class exams were proctored (to make sure no one used the internet) in small groups, and each exam included an honor pledge.
Yes, this course is necessary for most engineering majors and focuses on certain applications exclusive to engineering.
Yes, Professor Bennett is an excellent educator, and the course is streamlined and organized. There were many opportunities to receive help, and all assignments were graded with clear feedback.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual "Q&A" during lecture times that involved a review of lecture material and practice problems.

In addition to the pre-recorded lectures, there were also optional class sessions held twice a week on the day ENAS 151 would normally meet. In these optional sessions, the professor would go over the lecture notes for the lesson of that day and students would be able to do practice problems applying the basic concepts from that lecture if they so chose.
Mainly prerecorded lecture, weekly office hours in place of class time
We also had semiweekly, non-mandatory meetings during scheduled lecture time during which the professor would review the lecture notes and assign in-class problems.
recorded lectures, and live help sessions
Pre-recorded lecture
Recorded lectures to watch on our own time, plus optional summary & practice sessions during the nominal lecture time over Zoom and peer tutor/office hours over Zoom.

There were virtual seminar office hour sessions that we could choose to attend in which the professor reviewed the corresponding recorded lectures for the week as well as provide us with some example problems to solve out relating to those recorded lectures.
Recorded lectures.
Recorded asynchronous lecture.
Recorded lectures with Q&A and drop-in help sessions
Optional in-person office hours/Q & A during regularly scheduled class times.
There was also a live review session of each lecture.
In class practice problems
This course included recorded lectures and optional virtual discussion sections during class time.

There was a recorded lecture, but there was also a supplementary "review section" that occurred during the normal class time where lecture was reviewed and a couple of practice problems were done in breakout rooms.
Prof. Bennett would host live sections where she would review content from recorded lectures.
The main lessons were through recorded lectures, but there were also an optional recap/discussion sessions with practice questions with every lecture.
some in person study sessions
We had two long lectures to watch each week, and there were Q & A sessions twice a week for each lecture that were optional.
recorded lecture with an virtual seminar / review.

1. recorded lecture
2. live virtual lecture
live and recorded lecture , office hours !
Office Hours
Zoom Synchronous Q&A
This course also provided in-person review/Q&A sections during class time.
Recorded lectures, as well as scheduled live virtual times to do practice problems.
